Transportation Manual

Introduction

Purpose: Transportation ensures that all drivers complete deliveries accurately, safely, and on time, while also serving as the liaison between drivers, customers, and internal departments.

Scope: Covers all transportation employees, supervisors, and their workflows, including school routes, street routes, backhauls, hotshots, equipment tracking, and reporting.

Team Structure

Mike Palma – Transportation Manager: Oversees department operations.

Delareese Delgado – Supervisor of Schools: Ensures school routes are completed by 2 PM.

Patrick Brown – Supervises alphabetical route IDs.

Victor Polanco – Supervises letter IDs and Connecticut routes, truck maintenance, fuel, cameras, cleaning, and safety compliance.

Chun Ng – Handles backhauls and unplanned “hotshots.”

Bernie – Handles backend operations, equipment tracking, and reporting.

Daily Workflow – Transportation Staff

Start of Shift (Approx. 2 AM)

Organize invoices, loading sheets, and route documents received from night clerks.

Assign drivers to routes and verify route IDs, keydrop documents, and e-jack batteries.

Track each driver’s equipment and ensure readiness for the shift.

Driver Monitoring

Track driver location and stops using IntelliShift.

Log remaining stops at 10 AM, 12 PM, 2 PM, 4 PM to monitor on-time completion.

Ensure school deliveries meet deadlines (latest by 2 PM).

Coordinate with nearby drivers to redistribute stops if someone is falling behind.

Issue Handling

Vehicle breakdowns: Contact Allegiance or Penske trucks; use in-house mechanics if possible.

Report truck issues in Telnet: 30, 18, date, route ID, E, 100, message, driver, location, follow, 1 (send), enter.

Customer issues: Merge calls with sales teams, resolve delivery errors, verify keydrops, and coordinate backhauls.

Safety issues: Monitor Netradyne cameras for speeding, hard braking, drowsiness, or distracted driving; enforce corrective action or bonus adjustments.

Driver Types and Responsibilities

A. School Drivers

Start times: Typically 5 AM.

Obtain documents, batteries (if applicable), and review loading sheets

Deliver products to schools, ensuring accuracy due to potential fines ($500 per case).

Key duties:

Follow loading sheets carefully.

Handle refrigerated and dry items efficiently.

Maintain professional interactions with school staff.

Track deliveries, mark invoices, and return all equipment.

B. Street Drivers / NYC Drivers

Start times: Manhattan – 3 AM, other zones – 5 AM.

Collect paperwork and equipment from dispatch.

Deliver to restaurants, stores, or keydrop locations.

Verify product against invoices, check cases for mispicks, and handle refrigerated/dry items with helper.

For keydrop stops: Photograph storage for verification, lock premises afterward.

Follow DOT rules, traffic regulations, and maintain safety awareness.

C. Tractor Trailer Drivers

Require CDL A license.

Deliver products to warehouses or other Driscoll Foods locations.

May perform transfers and backhauls.

Same verification processes as street drivers.

Ensure full trucks leaving and returning to optimize efficiency and revenue.

Backhauls and Hotshots (Chun Ng)

Pre-planned backhauls: Ensure trucks return with product for revenue optimization.

Hotshots: Unplanned deliveries to collect product quickly.

Track and coordinate with drivers for timely execution.

Equipment Management (Bernie / Victor)

Monitor all trucks, jacks, e-jack batteries, straps, blankets, and handtrucks.

Maintain and repair equipment, assign to responsible employees, and document in reports.

Daily reporting ensures all resources are accounted for, available, and ready.

Reporting and Documentation

IntelliShift: Track truck location, driver, stops, and completion.

Netradyne: Monitor driving behavior and enforce safety standards.

Telnet: Log vehicle issues, route problems, and communicate with internal teams.

Dispatch sheets: Document driver assignments, route completion, and keydrop statuses.

End-of-day: Cease routes in IntelliShift, ensure all reports are accurate for the next day.

Safety and Compliance

DOT rules: Hours of service, break requirements, vehicle inspections.

Road safety: Defensive driving, safe handling of refrigerated and dry products.

Incident management: Immediate reporting of accidents, vehicle issues, or customer complaints.

Equipment safety: Proper use of jacks, handtrucks, e-jacks, and securing loads.

Communication Protocols

Transportation acts as the central liaison between drivers, dispatch, sales, and warehouse.

All issues, delays, or customer concerns are communicated promptly.

Team members support each other and can cover for absences.

Overview

Transportation is essential to Driscoll Foods’ operations: ensures timely deliveries, driver safety, vehicle maintenance, equipment management, and customer satisfaction.

Effective teamwork, communication, and vigilance ensure operational efficiency, compliance with DOT, and maximized company revenue.
